fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19879].
  {panel}

Steps to reproduce (tested on j.a.c):

   1. Bring up any list of issues in the Issue Navigator.
   2. Save the list as a filter named "Test for Me"
   3. Add a new Gadget of type "Issue Statistics" to your dashboard
   4. Type "Test for Me" in the "Project or Saved Filter:" box to do the quick find.
   5. The filter does not appear in the list of filters

Typing "Test for" also does not work. It will search for the two character("Test","for") separately.
fields.summary: Issue statistics Gadget AJAX quick find in Project or Saved Filter field doesn't work properly
Show filter owner username in filter UI

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19874].
  {panel}

With the current mail handler, if Jira receives an email whose address is associated with a user that does not have permission to comment or create issues, the email is rejected. However, if the address is not associated with any user, and the handler has a reporterusername, then the comment will be added as that default user.

This ends in the absurd situation where a non existing user can add comments to a case, but an existing user cannot. This user could then create a bogus email account to add comments to the issue.

In my understanding, the logic of the handleMessage/getReporter mail handlers should be changed. For the previous case (existing user but no permissions) the logic should be:

# Get user from email
# If user exists, check if user has permission to perform operation
# If no permissions, fall back to reporterusername

I am aware that [JRA-16786] was raised in the past with a similar request, and the functionality was claimed to be like that by design. However, I think the situation I describe is a flaw in that design.

If the logic was as described before, we could have avoided creating the proxy commenter for SAC to fix [JRA-15431]. The proxy commenter performs the logic as described before (with some additional magic)
fields.summary: CreateOrCommentHandler should fall back to defaultreporter if email user does not have permissions to perform operation

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19873].
  {panel}

One of our projects now has over 32000 issues that each have attachments.
When a user went to give the 32,001 issue an attachment, the file system refused it because it has a maximum of 32000 file handles per directory.  
The problem is that each issue gets its own sub-directory underneath the project key in the attachment path.  
There needs to be some sort of arbitrary middle directory between the project key and the issue directory, similar to how photos are stored on SIM cards. Maybe group issues in groups by the fourth power of ten?  

For example, instead of 

/usr/local/jira/attachments/JRA/JRA-123456

have

/usr/local/jira/attachments/JRA/120000/JRA-123456

For now we've moved the 1,000 oldest attachments to another directory, effectively deleting them from the Jira web site.  
So we have a couple weeks to come up with some patch for this or we keep effectively archiving or deleting old attachments.

I understand from our OS folks that it would be possible to recompile the kernel to have a higher maximum file handle setting.  However, my management wants to pursue an application solution rather than risk the OS recompilation solution.

Here is the error reported in the logs: 
{noformat}
2009-11-23 10:15:37,371 TP-Processor94 ERROR [jira.issue.fields.AttachmentSystemField] Error occurred while creating attachment.
com.atlassian.jira.web.util.AttachmentException: Cannot write to attachment directory. Check that the application server and JIRA have permissions to write to: /usr/local/jira/attachments/NOV/NOV-83753

        at com.atlassian.jira.workflow.SimpleWorkflowManager.createIssue(SimpleWorkflowManager.java:217)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.managers.DefaultIssueManager.createIssue(DefaultIssueManager.java:378)

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19841].
  {panel}

h3. Background:
+Created vs. Resolved Issues Report+ is great but unfortunately tells only one side of the story. Let's assume that process is something like this:
# A reporter creates a new issue
# A developer resolves the issue
# A tester closes the issue or reopens it

Now, there are a few interesting figures to follow:
* created vs. resolved (in the box already), tells how developers can manage their workload
* resolved vs. closed, tells how testers can handle their workload
* resolved vs. reopen, tells something about the quality of development

----
h3. Suggestion:
Enhance the current +Created vs. Resolved Issues Report+ so that a user can select freely what statuses to compare. Consider also adding several statuses together (e.g. created + reopened vs. resolved + closed). It is alright to have a single chart for each of the compared pairs but it would be even better to configure a single chart to show several pairs.
fields.summary: Enhance Created vs. Resolved Issues Report
JIRA should be invoking jQuery.noConflict so that if plugins redefine jQuery we still control the definition of $

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19813].

{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 23 April 2015|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this issue. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with JIRA.

At this time, this suggestion is not on the JIRA development roadmap. Please remember that jira.atlassian.com is one of many inputs for the JIRA roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

I understand that our decision may be disappointing. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.

Regards,
Dave Meyer
[dmeyer@atlassian.com|mailto:dmeyer@atlassian.com]
Product Manager, JIRA Platform
{panel}

Steps needed to replicate the problem:
# create a test message in Outlook that consists an image significant in size e.g. 1280 x 1024,
!TestImage.jpg|thumbnail!
# copy the image to clipboard,
# in JIRA navigate to a test issue > 'Attach screenshot' and paste the image.
The image gets cropped as per below example
!AttachedTestImage.jpg|thumbnail!

If the original image is 'Pasted Special' to MS Word as any of the support image formats, the image gets cropped too. However, if the image is just 'Pasted' or pasted as HTML Content the image retains its original size.
fields.summary: Images pasted from Outlook 2007 get cropped

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19766].
  {panel}

{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 28 July 2017|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

We're pleased to announce that customizable and rename-able gadget titles are now supported in JIRA Cloud. If you are the owner of a dashboard, you can give a gadget a custom title by clicking the configuration dropdown menu and choosing "Rename".
!New_1.png|thumbnail!  !new_2.png|thumbnail!  !new_3.png|thumbnail! 

The screenshots above are from the new JIRA UI and navigation experience that is currently being progressively rolled out to JIRA Cloud. This feature is also supported in the existing UI.
 !old_1.png|thumbnail!  !old_2.png|thumbnail!  !old_3.png|thumbnail! 

Thanks for your patience. We're looking forward to your feedback.

Regards,
Dave Meyer
JIRA Product Management
{panel}

Hi,

Jira users in my company report that the Project Summary page does not show all charts they would like to see. I have suggested that they could create a dashboard containing all relevant charts, but they complain that they cannot name the gadgets as they would like. 

For example the chart which is presented as 'Issues: 30 Day Summary' at the Project Summary page, could be placed at the dashboard, but its name is set to 'Created vs Resolved Chart: <Project Name>'. That would be great if users could edit the title.

Thank you,
Lukasz
fields.summary: Editing gadget titles

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19686].
  {panel}

Any java written application which interfaces with JIRA as a client, via the SOAP and/or XML/RPC interface, because they are themselves their own JVM, maintain a list of 'clean' and 'dirty', references to objects which the client knows about, across the wire.

When a remote client of JIRA calls a regular System.gc() as a part of it's usual automated garbage collection routine, it will notify the remote peer (in this case, JIRA), that any objects it was holding, of which JIRA was tracking in it's own reference object graph, are now dirty and those references should be cleaned.

Currently the Hotspot JVM performs this action as a serial, single-threaded System garbage collection. This can lead to rare circumstances whereby a remote client, if poorly written, or resource starved in the JVM, can fatally spam JIRA with full system GC calls until (if) it recovers.

The effect is similar to:
{noformat}378.030: [GC [PSYoungGen: 13733K->10886K(418816K)] 257769K->254922K(1336320K), 0.0438305 secs] [Times: user=0.05 sys=0.00, real=0.05 secs] 
378.074: [Full GC (System) [PSYoungGen: 10886K->0K(418816K)] [ParOldGen: 244036K->244138K(917504K)] 254922K->244138K(1336320K) [PSPermGen: 66190K->66190K(135168K)], 1.5175107 secs] [Times: user=4.92 sys=0.05, real=1.51 secs] 
379.924: [GC [PSYoungGen: 15258K->712K(435328K)] 259396K->244850K(1352832K), 0.0091928 secs] [Times: user=0.00 sys=0.00, real=0.02 secs] 
379.933: [Full GC (System) [PSYoungGen: 712K->0K(435328K)] [ParOldGen: 244138K->240486K(917504K)] 244850K->240486K(1352832K) [PSPermGen: 66592K->66590K(131072K)], 1.6306610 secs] [Times: user=4.53 sys=0.00, real=1.63 secs] 
382.535: [GC [PSYoungGen: 19106K->11462K(431104K)] 259592K->251948K(1348608K), 0.0230824 secs] [Times: user=0.06 sys=0.00, real=0.03 secs] 
382.558: [Full GC (System) [PSYoungGen: 11462K->0K(431104K)] [ParOldGen: 240486K->240176K(917504K)] 251948K->240176K(1348608K) [PSPermGen: 66648K->66646K(131072K)], 1.3173999 secs] [Times: user=4.14 sys=0.00, real=1.31 secs] 
383.926: [GC [PSYoungGen: 12066K->5636K(446080K)] 252242K->245812K(1363584K), 0.0219822 secs] [Times: user=0.05 sys=0.00, real=0.03 secs] 
383.949: [Full GC (System) [PSYoungGen: 5636K->0K(446080K)] [ParOldGen: 240176K->245655K(917504K)] 245812K->245655K(1363584K) [PSPermGen: 66668K->66668K(131072K)], 1.2802751 secs] [Times: user=4.03 sys=0.00, real=1.27 secs] 
385.301: [GC [PSYoungGen: 7271K->224K(441408K)] 252926K->245879K(1358912K), 0.0217929 secs] [Times: user=0.03 sys=0.00, real=0.03 secs] {noformat}
Rendering the installation incapacitated.

From [Sun|http://java.sun.com/javase/technologies/hotspot/gc/gc_tuning_6.html#other_considerations]:

{quote}Another way applications can interact with garbage collection is by invoking full garbage collections explicitly by calling System.gc(). This can force a major collection to be done when it may not be necessary (i.e., when a minor collection would suffice), and so in general should be avoided. The performance impact of explicit garbage collections can be measured by disabling them using the flag -XX:+DisableExplicitGC, which causes the VM to ignore calls to System.gc().

One of the most commonly encountered uses of explicit garbage collection occurs with RMI's distributed garbage collection (DGC). Applications using RMI refer to objects in other virtual machines. Garbage cannot be collected in these distributed applications without occasionally collection the local heap, so RMI forces full collections periodically. {quote}Alternatively,{quote}The frequency of these collections can be controlled with properties. For example,

	 java -Dsun.rmi.dgc.client.gcInterval=3600000 -Dsun.rmi.dgc.server.gcInterval=3600000 ...
 
specifies explicit collection once per hour instead of the default rate of once per minute. However, this may also cause some objects to take much longer to be reclaimed. These properties can be set as high as Long.MAX_VALUE to make the time between explicit collections effectively infinite, if there is no desire for an upper bound on the timeliness of DGC activity.{quote}

Originates from [CSP-38789|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/CSP-38789]. Explicit remote GC can be completely disabled (ignored) via {{-XX:+DisableExplicitGC}} in Tomcat startup parameters, under Sun Hotspot. Recommend we add this to the distribution startup parameters. Ignoring client requests for GC should not have any impact moving forward as JIRA has already been notified that the object is dirty, or dereferenced, and will reclaim it as part of normal collections.
fields.summary: disable distributed garbage collection via RMI

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19644].
  {panel}

This feature was removed per http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-15660

I have tried to use the setting set to false and true and see no change.

Steps to reproduce

Edit the C:\a\JIRA-Enterprise-3.13.4\atlassian-jira\WEB-INF\classes\jira-application.properties and add the following line to the very end of the file

jira.option.bulk.send.notifications=false

Restart JIRA
Perform a bulk edit
See that the box is checked and slam head on desk.

I repeated the same to see if by setting it to "true" I would have success. The same behavior was seen.

Is there a workaround to have the default behavior of bulk edits not to notify folks via email? Is there another setting we can use in jira-application.properties or another properties file that could turn off email notifications for bulk edits? I appreciate any help in this matter.
fields.summary: The default setting for Bulk Operations is set to "Send Email for this Update".  We would like to change the default setting to "Not send email for this update" instead of having to uncheck the silly box every single time we perform bulk operations

fields.description:
Apparently the styling for JIRA 4 takes advantage of the ability to suppress the focus box (dotted outline) on active links. Perhaps it annoys some people, but for those of us who prefer the speed of keyboard-only navigation over the mouse, the loss of that context-identifier is a big issue.

Being able to select a style that will show the focused item would be a big gain for accessibility.
fields.summary: allow viewing focus box

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19638].
  {panel}

There is currently no way of accessing the gadget-editing window via keyboard until the gadget header icons are made visible by mousing over the header. Once the mouse is over the header, everything except moving the gadget around the dashboard is available via keyboard.

Possible resolutions include:
* an option to make gadget menu icons always visible
* a hidden element in the gadget header that can receive focus, at which point the icons become visible and available (the hidden element should be "visible" to screen readers)
fields.summary: access gadget editing controls/menu via keyboard

fields.description:
Hi

Currently when we log time against an issue, the activity stream shows something like:
    Joe Bloggs changed the Time Spent to '167400' on XYZ-1234 

It would be much more helpful to show something like:
    Joe Bloggs worked for 30m on XYZ-1234
or
    Joe Bloggs updated the work done to 5h 45m on XYZ-1234 

Thanks
fields.summary: Improve Activity Stream detail shown for worklog updates
Is it possible to cutomise the layout of the issue screens?

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}

While investigating JRA-19612, I noticed that the translations for unit.hour & unit.day are inconsistent. Some languages have english, while others don't. Review these to determine whether they are correct.

pleschevs-Mac-Pro:etc pleschev$ grepprop "core.durationutils.unit.hour"
./languages/ca_ES/com/atlassian/jira/web/action/JiraWebActionSupport_ca_ES.properties:core.durationutils.unit.hour = {0}h
./languages/da_DK/com/atlassian/jira/web/action/JiraWebActionSupport_da_DK.properties:core.durationutils.unit.hour={0}t
./languages/de_DE/com/atlassian/jira/web/action/JiraWebActionSupport_de_DE.properties:core.durationutils.unit.hour = {0}h
./languages/default/com/atlassian/jira/web/action/JiraWebActionSupport.properties:core.durationutils.unit.hour = {0}h
./languages/en_US/com/atlassian/jira/web/action/JiraWebActionSupport_en_US.properties:core.durationutils.unit.hour = {0}h
./languages/es_ES/com/atlassian/jira/web/action/JiraWebActionSupport_es_ES.properties:core.durationutils.unit.hour = {0}h
./languages/fr_FR/com/atlassian/jira/web/action/JiraWebActionSupport_fr_FR.properties:core.durationutils.unit.hour = {0}h
./languages/hu_HU/com/atlassian/jira/web/action/JiraWebActionSupport_hu_HU.properties:core.durationutils.unit.hour={0}\u00f3
./languages/ja_JP/com/atlassian/jira/web/action/JiraWebActionSupport_ja_JP.properties:core.durationutils.unit.hour={0} \u6642\u9593
./languages/tr_TR/com/atlassian/jira/web/action/JiraWebActionSupport_tr_TR.properties:core.durationutils.unit.hour = {0}s

fields.description:
If an issue has no time tracking logged against it, we do not want to see a row with "Time Tracking: Not Specified".  This takes up valuable space on the view screen with no value to the viewer. 

If no time tracking data has been logged then don't show that row.
fields.summary: Remove Time Tracking "Not Specified" from issue view screen
API access to customfield information

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19607].
  {panel}

The AttachFile tag currently does not have the *Attached By* attribute. 

This attribute would be very useful when importing data into JIRA, where there is a different author of each attachment (this is a normal case when migrating projects from a different issue tracking system).

Currently JIRA sets this field to user who run the script - which is not always true.

The problem is that this *Attached By* field cannot be changed easily.
fields.summary: Allow AttachFile jelly tag to specify the "Attached By" attribute for an attachment

fields.description: When hovering the mouse over the "Watcher" count, it'd be nice if the tooltip listed the people currently watching the issue.
fields.summary: Watcher list - Tooltip
Roadmap max issues - needs to be configurable by application properties
restful URLs for named filters
Report showReport() does not actually block access to the report
External User Management: Edit Sign-In/Sign-Up/Edit Profile/Password Links

fields.description:
It would be good if JIRA showed resolved issues in a different style in the issue navigator. Perhaps their text and links could be grey instead of blue and black or something like that.

(By the way, I don't think strikethrough is a good solution here, despite what JIRA does with resolved issue keys like CONF-101.)
fields.summary: Show resolved issues in a different style in Issue Navigator

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19589].
  {panel}

I request that the filterpicker.jsp and the managefilters.jsp not populate the issue count on the server side and instead return the page without the issue count and have it filled in later asynchronously like the Favorite Filters portlet in Jira 3.13.

I've cloned this from JRA-16959 which was resolved as a duplicate.  I agree that the Favourite Filters portlet performs well as of 3.13.  

The ManageFilters screen and the FilterPickerPopup window launched from portlet configuration are still very slow.  Our Manage Filters screen takes about 15 seconds to load. It takes about 45 seconds to load the My tab in Manage Filters. The Filter Picker Popup takes about 15 seconds to load as well...until I disabled the issue count column in the JSP...after which it loads instantly.

And in JRA-8106, Vincent notes that he encounters similar some performance problems with Issue Filer Management which are not related to JRA-16959. He writes, {quote} In our instance, as Administrator, I am able to see many Filters (8 filters per Project and more than 200 projects).
Due to theses figures, in JIRA 3.10, I did use any more the Filter Portlet.
Since JIRA 3.13.x, I encounter the same performance problems, for the Portlet (normal !) but also for the ManageFilters page.
It appears a priori that each filter is systematically executed in order to provide the Issue count.

May we consider an enhancement of these two features (Portlet and ManageFilters page), where Issue count are calculated periodically and stored in order to have the figures as estimate values, but not systematically recalculated. {quote}
fields.summary: Bad Performance due to Issue Count recalculation in ManageFilters and FilterPickerPopUp
Z-order not respected when installing 'bjewelled' as gadget on a dashboard

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19568].
  {panel}

secure/admin/jira/ViewApplicationProperties.jspa
secure/admin/jira/EditApplicationProperties!default.jspa

These are two separate web pages with completely different layouts. It would be helpful to have 1 webpage instead of two, so you can make changes more directly. This is such a core part of site administration, please improve its usability.

Have something (button or checkbox), either for the whole page, or for each section, or for each item, to enable editing the configuration, so that you have to deliberately make changes, and prevent an accidental change by clicking on something by mistake.

When you are making changes, keep track of which items have been changed, and highlight them. It should be easy to verify that I have changed exactly one setting.

The help text (which only shows up on the edit page) should be toggle-able somehow, so it doesn't clutter up the page when you know what you're doing. On the other hand, you shouldn't have to go to the edit page just to see the help text. Allow me to turn it on or off if I need it. And maybe force it to be visible when you are editing a particular item.
fields.summary: combine display + edit pages of General Configuration

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19567].
  {panel}

Here's what I see under Global settings:
============
Attachments
Bamboo Servers
CVS Modules
System Dashboard
Events
FishEye Configuration
Perforce Job Integration
General Configuration
Global Permissions
Issue Linking
Look and Feel
Mail Servers
Sub-Tasks
Time Tracking
Trackbacks
User Defaults
Workflows
GreenHopper

It's not in alphabetical order; therefore you have some way (maybe this is just hardcoded HTML?) of ordering it to your liking. The current ordering is really awful because you have to scan through all these lists to find what you think you need. I would suggest the following:

General Configuration

Attachments
Dashboard (rename from System Dashboard)
Events
Global Permissions
Issue Linking
Look and Feel
Mail Servers
Sub-Tasks
Time Tracking
Trackbacks
User Defaults
Workflows

Bamboo Servers
CVS Modules
FishEye Configuration
GreenHopper
Perforce Job Integration

======

1. Separate global configuration. That's the most important menu to find, it should be *really* obvious how to find it.
2. Separate out the optional modules.
3. This gives you 3 groups, put all the items in alphabetical order.
fields.summary: reorganize "global settings" area of Administration to make it more usable

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19534].
  {panel}

Raised from a support request from a customer

We normally specify a defect as fixed in a particular build of a version of the project.
We have created custom field in the create defect screen to display the build number; but it requires to be pre-populated in the Project Admin screen where we add the components and versions.

1. We need to add builds under every version in the Project Admin screen.
2. This build numbers should be accessible to multiple custom fields. (eg., Reporter build, Confirmer Build and Resolver build)
fields.summary: Need a mechanism to add a build number under the version number in a Project

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19533].
  {panel}

When your operating system has its timezone set to "Brazil" or "America/Sao_Paolo" or "GMT-3", there is a peculiarity in Javascript whereby the following happens:

Evaluating
{{javascript:document.innerHTML=new Date(2009,09,17)}}
produces the output
bq. Sat Oct 17 2009 00:00:00 GMT-0300 (BRT)

and

evaluating
{{javascript:document.innerHTML=new Date(2009,09,18)}}
produces the output
bq. Sat Oct 17 2009 23:00:00 GMT-0300 (BRT)

This is causing a bug in our calendar popup picker used for dates in JIRA, where for instance in 2009, the 17th of October is repeated twice, as shown in the screenshot. The problem repeats every October.

Similar problems could exist with other timezones and months. Brazil is different from Australia in that DST takes effect at Midnight.

The problem with the date picker only occurs when:
* The time component is set to Midnight (i.e. its a date-only picker, or a date-time picker with the time set to Midnight)
* There is already a value set for the component
fields.summary: Calendar popup prints multiple dates in October when client is on Brazilian timezone

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19529].
  {panel}

JIRA now ships with bundled plugins that have translations of their own, separate from those in JiraWebActionSupport.properties

For instance, the dashboard has "Add Gadget". If you want to translate then you need to

- unzip the file WEB-INF/classes/com/atlassian/jira/plugin/atlassian-bundled-plugins.zip
- figure out which plugin owns the string you want to translate
- unjar the jar
- add your translations
- re-jar the plugin
- rezip the bundled-plugins.zip
- start JIRA and see if it worked

We don't document this anywhere right now.
fields.summary: Need to document how to translate bundled plugins

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19517].
  {panel}

Let's say you are an administrator and you want to edit a project's permission screen. And it's been a while since you've done this.

First you go to Projects and select the project you want. Oh wait. No administration functions here.

Then you go to the Administration tab, then select Project. It pops up a list of projects. Great! There are 3 choices, "View Edit Delete". You pick "Edit" since you are changing something. Oh wait, it's just the main project metadata (name, picture, etc). This is confusing.

Finally you go back and you pick "View". This shows all the project details besides the main project metadata. Here's where you can actually edit the major settings of a project, not on the "Edit" page but on the "View" page.

=====

Some suggestions for improved usability.

1) Get rid of the separate "View" "Edit" "Delete" screens and the "Operations" column on the "Administration" page. Combine them together. All 3 of them allow administrators to modify a project. It's too confusing to remember when I have to use "View" to edit a project setting, and when I have to use "Edit" to edit a project setting.

2) For "Delete", have a button or link that says Delete Project, but add a note below the button or link that says "(You will be asked to confirm)" or something. It's disconcerting to see "Delete" and think "Wait... if I'm not 100% sure, will clicking this immediately wipe the project away forever?"

3) On the regular Projects tab, when you select a project, add an "Administration" tab for administrators, so that you can modify the project settings from here, and are not forced to go to the Administration->Projects page.
fields.summary: Simplify project administration through more consistent/uniform access to project administration

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19511].
  {panel}

{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 19 Jan 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this issue. Your feedback is key to helping us understand how you use JIRA so we can continue improving your experience. We have reviewed this issue over the last few days.

Speed and performance are a priority for us. While there is still room for improvement when it comes to load times of the Dashboard, we believe at this point we have made sufficient progress to close this request. We continue investment in performance and more improvements are on ther way.

There was significant effort put into transformation of Gadgets to Dashboard Items. There are still some Gadgets pending transformation. The Activity Stream gadget being the heaviest, and it is scheduled for transformation within next 6 months. We expect further high impact on Dashboard performance from this. We also made some improvements in the front-end by removing DCL handlers.

In JIRA Cloud instances, Dashboard loading time still sometimes suffers from the fact that for ~25% of user sessions it is the first page after login, and therefore it's affected by cold caches and resources download. The solution here is not to improve the Dashboard anymore but to fix cold caches and resource delivery. We’re working on it.

To benefit from the above mentioned improvements we recommend for JIRA Server customers to upgrade to at least JIRA 6.4. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.

Regards,
Daniel Franz
dfranz at atlassian dot com
Principal Product Manager, JIRA Platform
{panel}
  

Dashboard is taking way more time to load than previous version. Everyone noticed it here and it is a major downgrade from 3.13.

On our local network, the dashboard is noticeably slower. From outside on SSL connection, it is annoying.

It seems like there is an load of HTTP requests made each time dashboard is load. Could'nt gadget be sent with the main page instead of being loaded after?
fields.summary: Excessive Dashboard loading time

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19479].
  {panel}

I installed JIRA on a hosted Windows server that was running IIS and other web sites on port 80. I needed to expose JIRA on a port that was open to the firewall (i.e. port 80) and using a URL that customers would find friendly, such as http://support.mycompany.com/jira. I walked through these two docs:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Configuring+IIS+with+Tomcat
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Integrating+JIRA+with+IIS

but I still had several major issues that prevented the site from working. Please add these steps and troubleshooting items to your IIS integration docs:

A) Grant Windows ACL permissions to the c:\tomcat_iis_connector folder. Right-click the folder, go to the Security tab, ensure that you grant Full permissions for the IIS_WPG group (or the Identity used by the Application Pool if it does not belong to the IIS_WPG group). Then click the Advanced button and select this option: "Replace permission entries on all child objects with entries shown here that apply to child objects". Click OK.

Troubleshooting: Ensure that you perform step A if you have any of the following problems:
  1) The ISAPI Filters tab shows a red arrow for the isapi_redirect.dll filter added earlier.
  2) You receive a blank response from your custom URL (http://support.mycompany.com/jira)
  3) A log file is not created within the c:\tomcat_iis_connector folder when you restart IIS and access your custom URL.

B) After creating the "jira" virtual directory, grant the Windows ACL Read permission to the Internet Guest Account (typically IUSR_servername) or whatever identity you have selected in your web site Directory Security for anonymous users.

Troubleshooting: If you receive an HTTP 401 (access denied) error from your custom URL (http://support.mycompany.com/jira) then ensure that you have done step B.

Troubleshooting: If JIRA responds on your custom URL (http://support.mycompany.com/jira) you may see the following error for each of the gadgets: "Error loading gadget: org.apache.shindig.gadgets.GadgetException: Unable to retrieve gadget xml. HTTP error 500". This occurs when the JIRA server is unable to resolve the domain name of your custom URL. If your server is hosted or for some other reason cannot resolve support.mycompany.com, then add the following entry to the C:\WINDOWS\SYSTEM32\DRIVERS\ETC\HOSTS file:  127.0.0.1  support.mycompany.com
fields.summary: Things to add to JIRA/IIS integration docs

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19465].
  {panel}

Hello,

while not exactly reproducible (probably an OOM at some stage during the very first installation), JIRA 4 can fail to deploy the bundled plugins successfully and core functionality may be missing from the application.

Subsequent restarts don't detect this condition and JIRA persists in this dysfunctional state until the {{home}} folder is cleared. It would be useful if the startup process verified plugin deployment and automatically repeated the process when necessary.

Possible symptoms of the problems are: missing project settings such as categories, issue type schemes, issue security schemes, field configuration schemes, workflow schemes etc... 

Regards,
Edoardo
fields.summary: JIRA should check on startup for incorrect core plugins deployment

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19463].
  {panel}

At the moment there's one global switch to turn the access to the Remote API on or off.

Sometimes you want finer control. For example, when you've made some customatizations or added some plugins that rely on information on the screens presented to the user. (Either to work correctly or to inform the user correctly). 

In this case you want to have control over who can access the Remote API, and who is forced to use the web interface. In our caser I would like to only grant remote api permission to members of the group 'isaac'.

A global permission would fit the bill nicely. 

You could go even further by making the permission part of the permission schemes to allow per project configuration.
fields.summary: Add Global Permission 'Allow access to remote api'
Improve documentation of JIRA remote api
Investigate the publishing of jira-subproject-plugins in our maven repo

"Distinct" qualifier in JQL

fields.description:
There is currently no functionality for viewing the change history items of an issue or issues in a manner which is acceptable for reporting or printing.

Furthermore, the existing issue views only print the comments of an issue; they do not allow you to choose which tab panel is included in the view.
fields.summary: Issue view which includes the change history items of the issue

fields.description:
The way the "Add Attachment" UI component can be used is different across browsers.

* Firefox shows the path in a text box, but it can't be modified
* IE shows the path in a text box, but it can be modified
* Safari shows no path

IE is the only browser which allows you to "cancel" the adding of an attachment, by blanking out the text box which contains the path. For other browsers, once you have chosen a file with the UI component, you must upload *something* (either the file chosen or another one).

Perhaps we could add a UI widget that removes the component from the form, so that the file is not uploaded.
fields.summary: Add UI capability to remove attachments once added
Update Popular Issues view to include whether assigned and number of years / months / days open
Document how to see application exposed packages and components for use by plugins
addComment SOAP API

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19407].
  {panel}

Use case:

I created a search request and wanted to add it to my dashboard using the Filter Results gadget straight away. Instead, I had to go back to the dashboard, add a gadget, and then configure it.

It'd be nice if there was a quick way of doing this from the Issue Navigator screen - maybe an option from the Tools menu. You would have to prompt the user to save the filter first, unless we had a Results gadget that just took an arbitrary JQL string.

I just noticed that the Charts allow you to do this already. So it would be similar to this.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19397].
  {panel}

Hello,

The filter's "subscription" option comes very useful for creating a periodical email "digest" of a filter.
However, the user can only specify himself for the subscription list.

Imagine that a user would like to have a setup where a daily email is sent for a certain subscription to a select group of users. Currently the only way to ensure this is by having the select users subscribe individually. It is desirable to allow any user to expand the list of subscribers.

Thanks,
Elik
fields.summary: Expand options to create group filter subscriptions

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19383].
  {panel}

There are currently four distinct hues of blue used on the dashboard screen, which makes it look a bit inconsistent. How do these fit with the JIRA colour scheme?

The four colours are:

- top header: #003366
- bottom header: #3c78b5
- gadget header: #336699
- gadget menu background: #325c82

I think the gadget menu background should probably be #369, and perhaps the bottom header too.

(I won't even comment on the myriad shades of grey used, but there are way more than four.)
fields.summary: Gadget headers and menus use different hues of blue compared to header

fields.description: In version 4.0 on the Search Results screen, there is a useful drop-down Actions menu that contains almost all actions that can be performed on an issue. One is notable by its absence: Attach a Screen Shot. Could this be added?
fields.summary: Add "Attach a Screen Shot" to the Actions menu in Issue Navigator
Provide a way to configure Gadgets URL specifically

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19348].
  {panel}

It would be nice if the new smart menus would remember the last admin sections I visited (I think 5 would be good but it should be configurable from the jira-application.properties file)

The way I see it working is:

* Add javascript to the admin decorator (include a web resource rather than inline javascript).  This will add a click listener to all admin links.  This listener will do an ajax request to a REST end-point.  This listener doesn't stop the page navigating to the desired page.
* Rest end-point - This will take the id (from the id attribute of the anchor) and store it in persisted history
* Persisted history - create a AdminUserHistoryManager (very similar to ProjectUserHistoryManager)
* create AdminHistorySimpleLinkFactory (similar to ProjectHistoryLinkFactory) and add it to system-top-navigation-plugin.xml.

Will need unit tests for the AdminUserHistoryManager, AdminHistorySimpleLinkFactory and AdminHistoryResource (REST).

Selenium tests to for functional coverage.

Note. AdminUserHistoryManager should most probably just deal with keys (Strings).
AdminHistorySimpleLinkFactory will need to convert keys to WebItems to SimpleLinks.
To convert keys to WebItems - get all JiraWebItemModuleDescriptors from the PluginAccessor using a ModuleDescriptor predicate that checks for the link id.
Look at the SimpleLinkManager on how to convert these to SimpleLinks.  (Most probably extract this logic into a helper class).
fields.summary: Remember Admin pages I have visited and display the last 5 in the Admin menu
Inline Restore Defaults confirmation for dashboards

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19329].
  {panel}

Top item in the activity stream is under heading "October 05 - 10:00 PM"

Our date formats:
	Format	Example
  Time Format	kk:mm 'UTC'	14:41 UTC
  Day Format	EEEE kk:mm 'UTC'	Tuesday 14:41 UTC
  Complete Date/Time Format	yyyy-MM-dd kk:mm 'UTC'	2009-10-06 14:41 UTC
  Day/Month/Year Format	yyyy-MM-dd	2009-10-06
  Date Picker Format (javascript format)	d/MMM/yy (%e/%b/%y)	6/Oct/09
  Date Time Picker Format (javascript format)	dd/MMM/yy hh:mm a (%e/%b/%y %I:%M %p)	06/Oct/09 02:41 PM

h3. Note

Streams currently uses different formats for time an date:

* Time. It is always the value specified in the field "Time Format" in the Look & Feel config page. The time if not displayed if the date is today.
* Date. It varies, depending on the actual date:
** For today's dates:
*** < 1 minute:  "Moments ago"
*** < 2 minutes: "1 minute ago"
*** < 1 hour: "X minutes ago"
*** < 2 hours: "1 hour ago"
*** < 1 day: "X hours ago"
** Yesterday: "Yesterday at {{time}}"
** Last week: "{{dddd}} at {{time}}" (eg. Sunday at 09:00 am)
** Last year: "{{m}} at {{time}}" (eg. 11 May at 09:00 am)
** Older: "{{D}} at {{time}}" (eg. Sunday, 11 May 2014 at 09:00 am)

The time & date format specifiers are documented below:
* https://code.google.com/p/datejs/wiki/FormatSpecifiers#CUSTOM_DATE_AND_TIME_FORMAT_SPECIFIERS
* https://code.google.com/p/datejs/wiki/FormatSpecifiers#STANDARD_DATE_AND_TIME_FORMAT_SPECIFIERS

Note: the format specifier {{a}} is translated to {{tt}}, so the default time format ({{h:mm a}}) is actually interpreted as ({{h:mm tt}})
fields.summary: Activity stream date format does not use configured format
Request reference to the Issue object in the CustomFieldType interface method validateFromParams

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19155].
  {panel}

{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 4 January 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this issue. Your feedback is key to helping us understand how you use JIRA so we can continue improving your experience. We have reviewed this issue over the last few days; unfortunately we don't have any plans to support this in JIRA for the foreseeable future.

Please remember that jira.atlassian.com is one of many inputs for the JIRA roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].
 
I understand that our decision may be disappointing. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.
 
Regards,
Dave Meyer
dmeyer@atlassian.com
Product Manager, JIRA Platform
{panel}

I'd like to be able to create an activity stream based on a component in a project.

It seems to be the easiest way to accomplish this would be to allow filters for issues to serve as the feeding system for the activity stream.
fields.summary: Activity Stream should be able to pull in based on a filter

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19145].
  {panel}

When a Jira instance has a large number of issue, an optimise can cause HTTP threads to time out.  For example, on this instance, there are 190K issue with a 1.9G main index.  When the limit of 4000 issues is reached, the thread that causes that to be reached will kick off an optimised.  This means that the whole 1.9Gb index will be rewritten.  In this case, it took 111 seconds:

{noformat}
2009-09-17 17:17:06,293 http-8000-Processor49 INFO tstcreateissue73 62195x782165x2 1bxkl5q http://localhost:8000/secure/AddComment.jspa [jira.issue.index.DefaultIndexManager] Optimizing the
 index because 4009 issues have been re-indexed since last optimize. Threshold is 4000.
2009-09-17 17:18:27,154 http-8000-Processor32 INFO tstcreateissue230 62195x782163x8 779gde http://localhost:8000/secure/CreateIssueDetails.jspa [jira.issue.index.DefaultIndexManager] Optimize index completed in 111623ms.
{noformat}

This led to a timeout for a thread attempting to add a comment:

{noformat}
2009-09-17 17:18:57,865 http-8000-Processor32 ERROR tstcreateissue230 62307x782180x10 779gde http://localhost:8000/secure/AddComment.jspa [jira.issue.index.DefaultIndexManager] Wait attempt timed out - waited 30000 milliseconds
com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.IndexException: Wait attempt timed out - waited 30000 milliseconds        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.DefaultIndexManager.obtain(DefaultIndexManager.java:525)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.DefaultIndexManager.await(DefaultIndexManager.java:466)        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.DefaultIndexManager.reIndexIssues(DefaultIndexManager.java:330)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.DefaultIndexManager.reIndexIssues(DefaultIndexManager.java:282)        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.DefaultIndexManager.reIndexIssueObjects(DefaultIndexManager.java:292)
        at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor352.invoke(Unknown Source)        at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
        at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:597)        at com.atlassian.util.profiling.object.ObjectProfiler.profiledInvoke(ObjectProfiler.java:70)
        at com.atlassian.jira.config.component.SwitchingInvocationHandler.invoke(SwitchingInvocationHandler.java:28)        at $Proxy63.reIndexIssueObjects(Unknown Source)
        at com.atlassian.jira.event.listeners.search.IssueIndexListener.reIndex(IssueIndexListener.java:155)        at com.atlassian.jira.event.listeners.search.IssueIndexListener.issueCommented(IssueIndexListener.java:88)
        at com.atlassian.jira.event.issue.AbstractIssueEventListener.workflowEvent(AbstractIssueEventListener.java:112)        at com.atlassian.jira.event.issue.IssueEventDispatcher.dispatchEvent(IssueEventDispatcher.java:125)
        at com.atlassian.jira.event.issue.IssueEventDispatcher.dispatchEvent(IssueEventDispatcher.java:83)        at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.issue.AddComment.alertSystemOfComment(AddComment.java:101)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.issue.AddComment.doExecute(AddComment.java:85)        at webwork.action.ActionSupport.execute(ActionSupport.java:153)
        at com.atlassian.jira.action.JiraActionSupport.execute(JiraActionSupport.java:59)        at webwork.dispatcher.GenericDispatcher.executeAction(GenericDispatcher.java:141)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.dispatcher.JiraServletDispatcher.service(JiraServletDispatcher.java:181)        at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:729)
        at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:269)        at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.doFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:188)
        at com.atlassian.core.filters.HeaderSanitisingFilter.doFilter(HeaderSanitisingFilter.java:44)        at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:215)
        at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.doFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:188)        at com.atlassian.plugin.servlet.filter.IteratingFilterChain.doFilter(IteratingFilterChain.java:46)
        at com.atlassian.plugin.servlet.filter.ServletFilterModuleContainerFilter.doFilter(ServletFilterModuleContainerFilter.java:55)        at com.atlassian.plugin.servlet.filter.ServletFilterModuleContainerFilter.doFilter(ServletFilterModuleContainerFilter.java:41)
        at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:215)        at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.doFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:188)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.filters.accesslog.AccessLogFilter.executeRequest(AccessLogFilter.java:154)        at com.atlassian.jira.web.filters.accesslog.AccessLogFilter.doFilter(AccessLogFilter.java:133)
        at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:215)        at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.doFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:188)
        at com.opensymphony.module.sitemesh.filter.PageFilter.parsePage(PageFilter.java:119)        at com.opensymphony.module.sitemesh.filter.PageFilter.doFilter(PageFilter.java:55)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.filters.SitemeshExcludePathFilter.doFilter(SitemeshExcludePathFilter.java:40)
        at com.atlassian.core.filters.AbstractHttpFilter.doFilter(AbstractHttpFilter.java:31)
        at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:215)
        at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.doFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:188)
        at com.atlassian.plugin.servlet.filter.IteratingFilterChain.doFilter(IteratingFilterChain.java:46)        at com.atlassian.plugin.servlet.filter.ServletFilterModuleContainerFilter.doFilter(ServletFilterModuleContainerFilter.java:55)
        at com.atlassian.plugin.servlet.filter.ServletFilterModuleContainerFilter.doFilter(ServletFilterModuleContainerF
...
{noformat}
fields.summary: Index optimise on large instances can cause timeouts for some requests
TextUtils.closeTags() does not handle self closing input fields
Your Watches and Your Votes actions should allow sorting and filtering of resolved issues

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19134].
  {panel}

Because the project gadget is not complicated enough already.

Would love to add 2 more pieces of information to the gadget:
* Project Avatar - we should display the avatar (on all views?).  Though due to the fact that viewing this is based on permissions, you need a way to be able get this image either via a proxy (only for remote) or via an ajax call.  An ajax call may be easier.
* Project Description - for the detailed view we should add the project description.  This may blowout some layout...
fields.summary: Add more information to the detailed project view in the project gadget
Add the state of indexing information to the Submit Support Request feature.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19108].
  {panel}

This ticket is a follow up of JSP-43756.

Our business case is as follow :
* We are using Confluence as a requirement management tool to keep track of the User Stories
* When an enhancement is requested by a client, it is captured in JIRA
* When this enhancement is approved, we change the code and tie it back to the JIRA ticket using the Subversion Plugin
* We *would like* to change the user story to account for the enhancement, and tie this change to the Confluence page back to the JIRA ticket, in pretty much the same way we are doing in Subversion

We could enter the ticket number in the Confluence change comment, and have a plugin pick that up and link it to the JIRA ticket.

That way, we would have a link from the ticket to the change in the code and the change in the requirement. We would have a link from both the code and  the requirement using the change comment.

Currently I have only see the possiblity of linking the complete Confluence page to the ticket as opposed to a particular changeset of this page.
fields.summary: Provide a way to link a Confluence Changeset to a JIRA ticket
Allow properties in jira-application.properties to be overiden from command line
gadget minimum height sometimes too small to see config/edit menu in igoogle
Create a FAQ on issue visibility and editability
IE8's lookahead download will sometimes request invalid URLs

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19091].

{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 9 January 2017|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9|titleBGColor=#ebf2f9|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

We're pleased to announce that this suggestion was implemented in JIRA Server 7.3.

We'll keep you informed, once we decide to release this improvement to JIRA Cloud.

Please don't hesitate to contact us if you have any questions or feedback.

Regards,
 Dave Meyer (Cloud)
 Eve Stankiewicz (Server)
 JIRA Product Managers
{panel}
If you create a workflow with a few steps, but don't add any transitions to them, no transitions can be added and the steps cannot be deleted once the workflow scheme is associated to a project, even if you make a draft workflow.

As soon as you disassociate all projects from the workflow scheme, you can add transitions or delete the step.

How to reproduce:

1. Create a workflow.
 2. Create multiple steps in the workflow but add no transitions.
 3. Create a workflow scheme.
 4. Associate the workflow to an issue type in the workflow scheme.
 5. Associate the workflow scheme to a project.
 6. Create a draft of the workflow.
 7. Try to add a transition to any of the steps.
 8. Try to delete any of the steps.

This is not a support request, as I have a workaround: make sure every step has at least one transition before associating them to a project.
fields.summary: Allow to add transitions to a step on an active workflow even if it has no outgoing transitions when there are no issues in that step

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-19083].
  {panel}

{panel:title=Atlassian Status as of 12 November 2012|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5| titleBGColor=#3C78B5| bgColor=#E7F4FA}
Hi everyone,

Thanks so much for your votes and comments on this issue.

We're happy to announce that this new feature is resolved in JIRA 5.2, satisfying 171 votes!

The Filter Results Gadget in JIRA 5.2 now supports ordering of fields. The ability to order columns has also been added to the Assigned to Me, Voted Issues, Watched Issues and In Progress Issues gadgets.

Thanks for your patience and we hope you appreciate our open approach to feature requests.

Cheers,

Bryan
JIRA Product Management
brollins at atlassian dot com

{panel}

*Original description*
"Filter Results" gadget is a very nice gadget and it allows one to select the fields to display, however there is no option to control the field order.
fields.summary: Allow ordering of fields in gadgets
